name: Horror Beat Sheet
description: A beat sheet for horror novels and films by T.L. Bodine

cards.title: Evil Cannot Be Conquered, Only Delayed

children.text: --- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
End of Act 3: The Prestige

There is often a final scare or glimpse of the Monster, reminding us that victory in a horror story is only ever temporary. Whether the Hero have won or lost, their ordinary world has changed. Now is the time to showcase the outcome of the story and wrap any final storylines.
If the Hero failed in Beat 13, show the Monster relishing its victory in a changed world. Will the world stay like this, or is there another Hero in the wings?
If the Hero succeeded, show the new world and include a hint that the Monster may yet return.
No matter how good things seem, danger always lurks around the next corner...
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
This is kept brief in Scream because it’s the first in a franchise – but the final image is a fraction of a second glimpse of our monster Ghostface, giving the monster the final word.
Breakdown:
Act 3 makes up the final 25% of the story.
Beat 15 occurs around the 95% mark, concurrent with Beat 14.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Late Act 3: The Prestige

Now that the climax has been reached, the story must show the consequences of the sacrifice or decision the characters made. Did the Hero emerge victoriously, or did they succumb to weakness? Whatever the answer, this is the beat where the consequences are explored.
Show the consequences of whichever choice was made.
If a standalone book/film, wrap the character arcs for the Hero and all remaining characters.
If the Hero is victorious, show how they have transformed.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
In Sidney’s case, we keep this brief because it’s the first film in a franchise – we’ll be dealing with these consequences for quite a long time. In a stand-alone movie, this might be longer.
Breakdown:
Act 3 makes up the final 25% of the story.
Beat 14 occurs around the 90% - 95% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Middle of Act 3: The Prestige

Faced with the ultimate choice, the Hero either succeeds in defeating their internal conflict and winning against the Monster, or fails and ultimately succumbs to their weakness. Will the Hero make the choice to move forward or slide back to the comfort of their old ways? The higher the stakes, the higher the reward. This is a moment to once more put the reader on the edge of their seat in anticipation of what may happen. The outcome should not be obvious.
This is the climax of the story – make it dramatic and rewarding.
If the Hero succeeds in defeating their internal conflict and overcomes the Monster, show how they use all they have learned along the way to succeed.
If the Hero fails in defeating their internal conflict and succumbs to their weakness, show how/why they chose to slide back and not complete their transformation into a stronger character.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
Sidney has to kill her own boyfriend, and come to terms with the realization that she put an innocent man on death row for her mother’s murder.
Breakdown:
Act 3 makes up the final 25% of the story.
Beat 13 occurs around the 90% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Middle of Act 3: The Prestige

Victory comes at a cost. Both the internal and external conflict must be confronted together, and their defeat will leave the Hero irrevocably changed. They will need to confront their conflicts and fears to emerge victorious, but the choice may not be as easy as it seems.
While confronting the Monster, the Hero realizes that their internal conflict must be encountered and defeated to overcome it.
This is the hidden cost, which will irrevocably change the Hero.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
For Sidney, she now knows now that she was right all along to distrust Billy, and that the internal struggles – her mother’s death, her problems with intimacy – were all his fault, not hers.
Breakdown:
Act 3 makes up the final 25% of the story.
Beat 12 occurs around the 85% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Early Act 3: The Prestige
Armed with knowledge, the hero is emboldened to succeed at last. Where previously they had been running for their lives, the Hero now seeks out the Monster.
For the first time, the Hero approaches the Monster, rather than fleeing it.
They intend to enact their new solution to defeat it.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
Sidney turns the tables on the killers, using their own methods against them.
Breakdown:
Act 3 makes up the final 25% of the story.
Beat 11 occurs around the 80% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Beginning of Act 3: The Prestige
Some new piece of information comes to light that makes it clear how to defeat the Monster. This is usually the placement of a big twist.
The Hero gains new information on how to defeat the Monster.
This new information may be delivered by a Mentor or someone they seek out for help, or it may come through soul-searching and observation.
The Hero use their new information and tools to prepare for the next confrontation.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

In Sidney’s case, we have the revelation that not only is Billy not dead, but – GASP! – he was the killer all along. Or, well, one of them. The whole scheme comes to light here. And, most shocking of all, we discover that Billy killed Sidney’s mother as well, which ties up all of those internal and external conflicts together into a tidy package with a neat little bow.
Breakdown:
Act 2 makes up 50% of the story from 25% - 75%.
Beat 10 occurs around the 75% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
End of Act 2: The Turn

The confrontation has failed, the Monster is on the move, and the Hero is more isolated and in greater danger than ever before. The chase reaches a feverish pitch. The characters (that remain) come to the darkest moment of the story. The reader should feel there is no hope and no way to destroy the Monster.
Hope appears lost – perhaps someone very important has died, or the Hero has tried everything they can think of doing.
The link between the internal conflict and the Monster may become clear to the Hero.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

Sidney’s best friend is dead; almost everyone from the party has left; she’s alone with Billy and then – OH NO! – Billy gets stabbed, leaving her to fight off the monster on her own. Every attempt she makes to get help fails as the people she seeks help from are taken out one by one.
Breakdown:
Act 2 makes up 50% of the story from 25% - 75%.
Beat 9 occurs around the 65% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Middle of Act 2: The Turn

As the second act approaches its close, the Hero attempts to solve their problem, but fails due to not having all of the important information – in other words, the link between the internal and external struggle has not yet become clear to them. This may be a conflict with the Monster itself, or it may be an attempt to reconcile the character’s interior trouble; but either way, this confrontation is doomed because the character isn’t ready yet.
The Main Character attempts to destroy the monster.
They fail at the attempt as they do not yet possess the ability or needed skills/tools to do so.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

This is the portion of Scream where Sidney gives in and has sex with Billy in hopes that it might return some sense of “normal” to her life and allow her to move past her mother’s murder. But after they’re finished, Sidney realizes that didn’t fix her problem at all. Things are still weird with Billy, and she doesn’t feel any better.
Breakdown:
Act 2 makes up 50% of the story from 25% - 75%.
Beat 8 occurs around the 60% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Early Act 2: The Turn

Beat seven is the longest part – and the heart – of the story, the part where the problems brought up in the first act are teased out and examined. It’s what Blake Snyder would call the “Promise of the Premise,” or what the Hero’s Journey would call “The Road of Trials.” But in a horror movie, it’s the part of the story where the Monster grows increasingly dangerous and comes ever closer to catching hold of the Hero – hence The Chase. It’s also the part of the story where the link between the character’s internal and external struggle begins to become clearer as the character battles against both.
The Monster chases the characters.
The characters lack the skills to fight the Monster.
One or more people may die here.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

In Scream, we see Sidney continue to wrestle with the specter of her mother’s murder. Billy has been ruled out as a suspect by the police, but their relationship is still in trouble. And the audience is teased with glimpses of the killer and a few murders to keep things going. Once again, the characters make a decision that puts them on an isolated collision course – in this case, a party invitation that defies the curfew that’s meant to keep everyone safe.
Breakdown:
Act 2 makes up 50% of the story from 25% - 75%.
Beat 7 occurs around the 40% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Beginning of Act 2: The Turn

The moment where the threat becomes evident to the characters involved. This happens about 1/3rd of the way into the story, or at the beginning of the second act. In The Hero’s Journey, this is the “crossing the threshold” moment.
The first death or when the seriously spooky activity begins.
The danger becomes evident and unavoidable.
There's a marked increase in tension.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
Sidney gets attacked in her house, an event which also leads her to become suspicions of Billy, putting even more pressure on their strained relationship.
Breakdown:
Act 2 makes up 50% of the story from 25% - 75%.
Beat 6 occurs around the 30% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
End of Act 1: The Setup

Whether through a close encounter or just a quick brush, Act 1 ends with the first meeting of the characters and the Monster. The audience of course has seen the Monster in action already – but the fifth beat is about introducing it to the character who, up to this point, has only been struggling with their own inner demons. What’s important about plot point five is that the character doesn’t immediately realize how dangerous the threat really is.
Give the characters their initial contact with the Monster.
Show the characters unaware of the true threat the Monster poses.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
Sidney receives a threatening phone call and at first fails to take it seriously, going so far as to attempt to provoke it.
Breakdown:
Act 1 makes up the first 25% of the story.
Beat 5 occurs around the 25% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Late Act 1: The Setup

The characters have an opportunity to walk away before crossing the point of no return and fully entering the story. However, they decide to ignore the warning and proceed. This section provides a chance to show the thought process of the characters, build interpersonal tensions, and raise the overall stakes of the story.
Give the characters the opportunity to turn back, but show them choosing not to.
This beat can occur before or after the First Contact with the Monster.
Beats three and four often happen close together or are bundled into a single event.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

In this case, after we meet the rest of the important supporting characters – Sidney’s best friend, her insensitive boyfriend, and the weird tag-along friend Randy – we hear a literal warning from the school advising teens not to spend time alone or go out at night until the murderer is found.

But Sidney is on a collision course with the monster anyway. We know that horror relies on isolation, and we’re treated to a long sequence establishing just how alone she is as she returns to an empty house while her father is away on a business trip. She arranges for a friend to come get her, but for a moment, she is totally isolated. We also learn more crucial information about Sidney’s history, namely that her mother was brutally raped and murdered a year ago – an event that starts to make sense of some of her struggles with intimacy in her relationship.
Breakdown:
Act 1 makes up the first 25% of the story.
Beat 4 occurs around the 20% mark.

Middle of Act 1: The Setup
The characters make a choice that inadvertently isolates them or places them on a collision course with the monster. This is often where they decide to investigate the spooky house or go on a trip.
What choice do the characters make?
How does it lead to their isolation?
How does the decision put them on a collision course with the Monster?
Beats three and four often happen close together or are bundled into a single event.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

In this case, after we meet the rest of the important supporting characters – Sidney’s best friend, her insensitive boyfriend, and the weird tag-along friend Randy – we hear a literal warning from the school advising teens not to spend time alone or go out at night until the murderer is found.

But Sidney is on a collision course with the monster anyway. We know that horror relies on isolation, and we’re treated to a long sequence establishing just how alone she is as she returns to an empty house while her father is away on a business trip. She arranges for a friend to come get her, but for a moment, she is totally isolated. We also learn more crucial information about Sidney’s history, namely that her mother was brutally raped and murdered a year ago – an event that starts to make sense of some of her struggles with intimacy in her relationship.
Breakdown:
Act 1 makes up the first 25% of the story.
Beat 3 occurs around the 15% mark.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Early Act 1: The Setup

Now that we’ve made our contract with the audience, it’s time to introduce the Main Characters (if we haven’t already met them) and reveal their primary internal conflicts. All monsters are mirror images of the Main Character’s internal conflict.
Introduce the important characters.
Show their primary internal conflict.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:

We’re introduced to tender young Sidney Prescott, and quickly learn everything we need to know: She lives alone with her father; she has a boyfriend, Billy, who is upset at their lack of sexual intimacy and is bad at respecting boundaries. We don’t know exactly what’s happened yet, but we know from their introduction that something big has happened in Sidney’s recent past and that the baggage is causing trouble in her relationship.
Breakdown:
Act 1 makes up the first 25% of the story.
Beat 2 occurs around the 5% mark.

cards.title: The World is Not What it Seems

children.text: --- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Beginning of Act 1: The Setup

The opening beat is where the audience catches their first glimpse of the monster, or at least an early hint that the monster exists and of where the story will go. This may occur right away – often as a prologue – or after the Main Characters have been introduced. The opening is a promise to the audience, who will now eagerly wait to see that promise fulfilled.
Give the reader an early glimpse of the Monster or a hint that the Monster exists.
Allow the reader to see that the Ordinary World has something sinister just below the surface.
Example – Wes Craven's Scream:
In Scream, we’re introduced to Casey – who, in an iconic 11-minute opening sequence, receives an ominous phone call, discovers the caller is in her house, and is brutally murdered.

This opening sets up everything we need to know about the story’s premise: We know what to expect from the monster, catch a few hints of the darkly comedic tone of the film, and see plenty of blood and guts.
Breakdown:
Act 1 makes up the first 25% of the story.
Beat 1 should comprise approximately 5% of the story.
